title: Who will win the 2020 NBA Most Valuable Player Award?
preds:
Seems to be a straight-forward process...
"Antetokounmpo received 85 of 101 first-place votes and earned 962 total points from a global panel of 100 sportswriters and broadcasters as well as the Kia NBA Most Valuable Player Award fan vote." But why are they voting before the season's high (the finals) have ended?

Some early news reports today that Giannis has won his second straight MVP award: https://www.espn.com/nba/story/_/id/29913814/sources-milwaukee-bucks-giannis-antetokounmpo-wins-second-straight-mvp-award https://www.cbssports.com/nba/news/bucks-giannis-antetokounmpo-named-nba-mvp-for-second-straight-season-per-report/

EDIT:
It's really not clear to me, in what kind of procedure the MVP is elected or determined.
The Wesleyan Argus, e.g. as one of the most recent sources cites Giannis Antetokounmpo as the "likely MVP"
http://wesleyanargus.com/2020/09/17/nba-playoffs-recapping-the-turbulent-second-round/ while an extended version of ESPN glorifying James' "Greatness" implies, that this season's MVP has yet to be determined, and LeBron James has good chances to win his fifth such title of his career. "As the four-time MVP presses for another title, those who ousted James -- the San Antonio Spurs, Boston Celtics, Orlando Magic, Dallas Mavericks and Golden State Warriors among them -- reveal how their teams did it, and how the maturation of James has rendered some of their tactics moot."
(It may well be the editorial talks of a possible win next season...) https://www.espn.com/nba/story/_/id/29903595/how-six-teams-stopped-lebron-james-nba-playoffs Interesting by-facts about James: "No other player has statistically dominated the postseason the way the Lakers' supernova has. James ranks first all time in playoff games played, minutes, points, steals, field goals and free throws, and ranks in the top five in assists and 3-pointers. He has accumulated the most playoff win shares in NBA history, per Elias Sports Bureau, with 51.1. The man whose legacy he continues to chase, Michael Jordan, is second with 39.8."

https://www.sportscasting.com/drew-gooden-just-revealed-how-lebron-james-motivates-his-teammates-to-win/

Although LeBron and Harden had great seasons, Giannis Antetokounmpo's game statistics show he should be MVP. LeBron's team, the Lakers form a better support system than giannis' bucks and that's why it's remarkable that Giannis' stats are much better. He averaged nearly 30 points, 12 rebounds and 6 assists despite playing less than around 31 minutes per game. This shows he was great offensively and defensively. He's nominated for the Defensive Player of the Year as well.

Even if Giannis Antetokounmpo is a stand-alone giant in the season, I wonder how likely it is for him to become MVP if his team crashes out in the conference semifinals already (Miami Heat now leads 3 - 0 over Milwaukee bucks).
James Harden probably was the key player to Houston Rockets for advancing in the first round (4 - 3 vs OkCTh, Harden scored more than 30 points in 5 out of 7 games), and is less universal than Giannis Antetokounmpo when it comes to assists and rebounds, probably even steals per game. However, the Rockets now lead  1 - 0 over my own WC favorite, the LA Lakers, Harden again scored 36 points, so there's much consistency in performance. It probably comes down to whether the Rockets will advance to the finals, and Hardens performance in the finals. For the near term, I added him with a slim chance.
LeBron James seems to be the real team player, he is valuable for assists and rebounds, he is leading the "Game High" statistics for assists (16 in one game), and his true value became obvious if he was counter-factually not participating in games. As I understand the MVP, LeBron James is the player who, in total, fulfills this category best, even though his value is not measured by points (Anthony Davis leads the points statistics for the Lakers) and LeBron James is not "outstanding".
James Harden and LeBron James sort of cancel or rule out each other, but there is a significant chance one of them will be elected, depending on the finals.
Giannis Antetokounmpo,was as good as it gets during the season; post-season he seems to have lost his mojo a bit, and I lower his probability for a while - let's see if the Bucks can turn around their semi-final versus the Heat, which would be a strong signal for his eligibility, since he would then prove he could keep his team together even under stress (next and maybe last game: 06 September 2020).

I personally think LeBron's achievements this late in his career are more impressive, but Giannis is the best player on the best team. He is dominant on offense and defense, and the team is fully built around his strengths--it could not thrive without him. You could make a similar argument for LeBron with the exception that the Lakers could be an okay team with only Davis.

Reducing forecast  'hedge' a little further, even though only two players (in NBA history) have won both MVP and Defensive Player of the Year after a season. Meeting the crowd until the dust settles...
We all know Giannis is gonna win lol. I was gonna hedge a bit, but looks like I'll need to adjust to the crowd.

NBA MVP ladder declares Giannis as MVP presumptive: https://www.nba.com/mvp-ladder Giannis also has highest PER, VA, and EWA amongst Top 10 in above Ladder: http://insider.espn.com/nba/hollinger/statistics If I recall correctly, PER is a major indicator of value -- the last time the PER leader was not the MVP was Derrick Rose in 2011 Giannis also leads in WS/48. https://www.basketball-reference.com/leagues/NBA_2020_leaders.html Harden has highest VA, EWA, and VORP (having played more games than Giannis), but has 0% on crowd consensus and wasn't even among the Top 15 in the latest MVP ladder. I would go 1% Harden, but adjusting towards crowd, am going 100% Giannis.
Milwaukee is top seed in east because of Giannis.  Without him they'd be lucky to be 6th seed.

In 20 years there have been 5 repeat MVPs (two of which are held by the same player, Lebron James), which means everything else aside Giannis has a historical chance of around 25% to be a repeat. Each repeat improved in at least 3 of four categories: FG%, PPG, RPG, and/or APG. Giannis has improved his PPG and RPG while keeping his FG% and APG roughly constant. It's not a sure thing by any means, and may well depend on performances in the postseason and external factors (e.g. activism). Harden doesn't really have the stats or external factors to get the MVP, so he will depend on an exceptional performance in the playoffs to have a chance here.

Giannis was the best player on the best team and is certain to win. As a counterpoint, though, the basketball-reference MVP tracker gives him a much lower chance. [1] [1] https://www.basketball-reference.com/friv/mvp.html
Giannis is the best player on the team with the best regular season record. His team was the most successful, and he has the largest impact on his team’s success. He is by far most likely to win MVP.
Since the NBA is all about political activism, LeBron is being set to 100%.
